Headline.Para: Europe Plants a Flag in the Digital-Tax Debate; European Commission sees a chance to bring international change on its terms, Simon Nixon writes

LeadPara.Para: The European Union could hardly have chosen a more provocative moment to launch proposals for a new digital tax.

The EU's trade commissioner is currently in Washington trying to persuade the Trump administration to exempt the bloc from new U.S. tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, amid fears of a trade war. The U.S. and EU are at loggerheads over a range of other issues ranging from climate change to Iran to defense spending.

TailParas.Para: This was hardly the ideal time to announce what will be seen in the U.S. as a €5 billion tax grab aimed at American multinationals by taxing their European sales rather than their profits.

Some EU officials urged the European Commission to delay its announcement until at least after the U.S. tariff decision. But with an EU summit this week, the Commission wanted its proposals on the table—and so a new front in the trans-Atlantic war of words has opened up.

The Commission naturally rejects any suggestion that its proposed digital tax is directed against the U.S. or that it should be in any way linked to disputes over trade. After all, it has been working on its proposals for months, following an urgent request from EU leaders last September to respond to growing public concern that digital companies aren't paying their fair share of tax.

The Commission points out that the current international tax system was created more than 100 years ago and is badly adapted for a world in which the main assets of companies include intellectual property rather than bricks and mortar. The Commission recently estimated that aggressive tax planning by multinationals is costing EU governments €50-70 billion a year in lost corporate tax revenues and that digital companies are paying an effective tax rate of just 9% compared with an average of 25% among traditional businesses.

Indeed, the Commission argues that if action isn't taken at the EU level, then member states will take matters into their own hands. It reckons up to 10 countries are currently contemplating their own web taxes—not least the U.K., which is already consulting on its own "Google tax" which would require firms to pay taxes on U.K. royalties diverted to companies outside the U.K.
The risk is that member states making their own rules could undermine the cohesion of the single market and create damaging uncertainty for businesses.

The Commission insists that its own proposals have been calibrated to minimize disruption to the EU market for digital services: it proposes a levy of 3% on EU digital-services revenues on those companies with global revenues of more than €750 million and with digital-services revenues of more than €50 million in the EU single market. These taxes will be collected and then shared among EU member states according to where the users of those services live.

Of course, the Commission's protestations cut little ice with U.S. tech companies, who account for about half the 140 companies likely to be affected by the tax. The EU's accusation that digital companies don't pay enough tax takes no account of last year's major U.S. tax overhaul which will lead to U.S. companies with large overseas operations paying more U.S. corporate tax, saida senior executive at one U.S. tech giant.

Indeed, under the Commission proposal, the EU digital tax would be treated as a business expense for tax purposes, thereby directly reducing the amount of tax that would be received by the U.S. Treasury.

U.S. tech companies also argue that the proposal is shortsighted since companies with lower profit margins will be particularly hard hit, putting future investment at risk. They argue that if the EU wants to change the rules regarding who collects what tax, this should be agreed internationally.
The problem is that international efforts to change the rules appear to be going nowhere.

The EU insists that what it is proposing is an interim solution: its preferred solution is an overhaul of the international tax system including new global rules both on the way that corporate tax bases are calculated and how taxes are divvied up between countries to take greater account of where digital users are based.

Indeed, the Commission has also published new proposals for harmonizing the EU methodology for calculating corporate tax bases. Yet the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which has been leading efforts to find an international agreement since 2015, earlier this month admitted that its members were split over what if any action to take and set a new target for reaching an agreement of 2020.

The reality is that the Commission's proposals may be going nowhere too. EU decisions on tax must be taken by unanimity and a number of smaller member states in particular, not least Ireland, are deeply opposed to any digital tax.

Even so, the Commission is unlikely to give up easily: it sees an opportunity to get ahead of the OECD and bring about international reform on its terms. In this respect, the tax debate is part of the wider battle over the future of the global rules-based system.

The EU may be calculating that in tax, as in trade, a united EU can ultimately prevail in the competition to write the rules of the global system, thereby ensuring the success of its economic model. The risk, of course, is that the current tensions brings the system down.
